text:
Professor's Note: One way to remember the effects of changes in the risk-free
rate is to think about present values of the payments for calls and puts. These
statements are strictly true only for in-the-money options, but it's a way to
remember the relationships. The holder of a call option will pay in the future to
exercise a call option and the present value of that payment is lower when the
risk-free rate is higher, so a higher risk-free rate increases a call option's value.
The holder of a put option will receive a payment in the future when the put is
exercised and an increase in the risk-free rate decreases the present value of this
payment, so a higher risk-free rate decreases a put option's value.
